Christopher Plummer was superb as a man with early to mid-onset dementia - a performance equaled by Martin Landau, even if in a much smaller role. The pacing was deliberately slow, building to an impeccably-timed and well-disguised twist. Breaking Bad's Dean Norris was the proverbial cherry on top. His brief scene with Christopher Plummer - wow. His vitriolic dialogue was paced much like the film, slow at first but building to the explosive end. The palpable loneliness and hatred he spewed lead to the necessary conclusion, again, much like the rest of the film. Don't look for tons of action but well worth the time for a thoughtful, entertaining evening.

What a hopelessly convoluted and pathetic plot. Really! For those looking for a far better plot with mistaken identity, I heartily recommend Edgar Hilsenrath's "The Nazi and the Barber". Unfortunately not made into a movie yet! The overdramatisation in "Remember" is completely pathetic: the Holocaust isn't bad enough for some, apparently. No, we have to weave it into a completely incredible plot about someone who has Altzheimer and nevertheless goes on a mission to punish some Nazi's that got away. On the way he shoots a contemporary Nazi, or the son of one, who just happens to get in his way. Never mind about the ethics: Nazi's are the bad guys right? Doesn't matter when or where or who... I am sorry if I offend someone out there, I am Jewish myself, and an Israeli too, but don't you all think its kinda time to stop writing crap about the Holocaust and start writing some real drama again? By the way, my Aunt was a survivor of Auschwitz and I assure you all, she had better things to do than hunt Nazi's and take revenge on any racists she happened upon. She had a life to live and a story to tell and she did those things without all the pathos that Shoah revivalists seem to think is necessary.

Sorry but a compelling story does not always equal a good movie.  The script and parts of the story line are so predictable or unbelievable that it takes away from the real story and the brilliant acting of the main characters.  It is hard for me to believe that anyone would let a total stranger into their home and send them down stairs without knowing their name or why they are there or even announcing their presence.  The children are cute and acted good but do parents not tell their kids to not to talk to strangers any more.  Yes he is an older gentlemen but most kids are afraid of their shadows much less form friendships with older people in minutes on a bus or in a hospital room.  I really thought  Christopher Plummer's character was going to say "do want some candy little girl" Really? the story is just not believable.  The son does not act really worried about his dad when he arrives near the end of the movie and the final scene was unreal.  No one ran to call 911, cried or really responded in any emotional manner and the daughter accepts what a total stranger makes her father say while he has gun pointed at him. This could have been a very moving story and a wonderful film.  This is an example of how we have been dumbed down and conditioned to accept and praise  mediocrity for the sake of a noble subject matter.

"Remember", was a pleasant surprise I thought. Christopher Plummer is great as man on a mission to kill a former Nazi SS prison guard who murdered his family during the holocaust. CP was the epitome of cool when he was doing films in the 60's and he still can act. This film does an amazingly accurate portrayal of what 'dementia' looks like as we see Plummer struggle with his memory and mobility one minute, then be lucid and capable the next. Supported and directed on his quest by Martin Landau (who remains at the rest home they both reside in), Plummer eventually finds his prey, and that's when the film gets REALLY interesting. I won't give away the plot/ending but I really enjoyed the surprise/twist ending--I didn't see it coming. This is not a happy movie--its not meant to be. , but it is a worth your time & energy to see.

With the gradual dying out of the people who lived the Second World War stories and remembrances of these times start to fade.  In this remarkable movie in which Christopher Plummer plays an elderly Jewish man seeking a Nazi who was responsible for the deaths of his family in Germany more than 70 years hence we see that what transpired has not been forgotten by the participants.  Well in seeing this movie that may not really be true.  Memories sometimes play tricks on ones mind and remembrances may not be what they seem to be.
 The film has the character played by Plummer being guided by a disabled friend played by Marin Landau to follow all leads in search of this Nazi tormentor.  The story seems to be very predictable but in fact has many twists and turns made during his cross country search.  Plummers character has the beginnings of dementia so the instructions given by his disabled friend must be concise and clear.
 With all the twists and turns, the finale will leave you stunned.  This movie was well done and it is well worth watching.  To this day the search for these criminals continues as we see men and women in their 90s being tried and convicted of Nazi War Crimes.

Christopher Plummer plays an aging Holocaust victim who has dementia and has just lost his wife.  Prior to losing his wife, he promised to himself and a fellow resident (Martin Landau) at his nursing home to find the Nazi who killed his family at Auschwitz.  Since he has dementia, Landau writes down the steps in a letter, and Plummer follows them across the country to try to find the Nazi and kill him.
  I found the movie engrossing because of Plummer's performance, and I was willing to suspend my disbelief that a person with dementia would act this way or be able to cross the country with or without instructions--it's like the Bourne Trilogy in which the Bourne loses all his past memory for dramatic purposes, only more so because Plummer is supposed to be debilitated in the present by his disease and yet accomplishes some difficult tasks.  If you know someone with dementia, however, this particular trope may be too much to accept.
  Unlike many reviewers, I found the climatic ending unsatisfying.  It's not so much that it's been done before and the climatic scene was a little stilted in my opinion, but that Plummer's character was unmotivated by anything other than shock and maybe one earlier scene.  That's not enough.  We need to know more about his life after leaving Germany.  Having written that, it was an interesting movie about revenge and justice.  The only scene I could have done without was Landau explaining everything at the very end.  I suppose the director thought it necessary to show it wasn't dementia and who plotted the whole thing, but I didn't like it.

In a New York nursing-home 'Auschwitz' survivor 'Max Rosenbaum' (Martin Landau) a wheelchair-bound resident
befriends fellow patient 'Zev Guttman' (Christopher Plummer) who he's recognised from those those dark days of
70 years ago.
'Zev' has dementia and forgets things very easily including the loss of his wife 'Ruth' in recent times.
'Max' continually reminds 'Zev' that their families were murdered at the camp by Blockfuher 'Otto Wallisch' who
had emigrated to America all those years ago and has lived there ever since avoiding detection and punishment .
Revenge is very much on 'Max's' mind, though he is unable to seek out 'Otto' himself he convinces 'Zev' that he
should take up the challenge of hunting-down and administering justice on the war-criminal.
Much information has been gathered by 'Max' as he's found numerous locations where 'Otto' may be under an assumed
name, he writes down the locations and detailed list of instructions for 'Zev' to read over and over again to remind him of
his task.
He's been given the addresses of four possibles living under the name of 'Rudy Kurlander' and sets off on his journey....
he will frequently forget where he is or why he is there, only the letter will remind him of his aim.
He has purchased a firearm to carry out the task if and when he finds the target, his travels take him far and wide including
over the border into Canada though his first three contacts prove to not be who he seeks.
Meanwhile back in New York his son 'Charles' is going frantic, his father has walked out of the care-home and disappeared
without warning, the one pe, rson who has the answers 'Max' is saying nothing.
When 'Charles' finally gets a hint of where his father is, 'Zev' is on his way to confront a fourth 'Rudy Kurlander'.....will he
get there in time to prevent his father from administering justice ?
This is a superb tense and well portrayed drama with veteran actor 'Christopher Plummer' playing the role of 'Zev' magnificently.
A suspenseful  film with an unexpected twist in the tail......well worth a viewing.
A wonderfully intriguing story of unpredictable suspense as the character struggles with dementia while focused on a mission of revenge.

I never even noticed this movie until I saw the title and preview in litestream's pay-per-view movies. I thought it would basically be about an elderly Jewish man, living in a nursing home, who, after reading a letter, decides to get his vengeance on the Nazi who murdered his family. Well, yes. It is about that, but very different in character studies, with more than one twist. You know that the movie will not be elating, nor is there any humor. It is however, extremely emotional, leaving me weeping. It is filled with jarring scenes and some of the best acting you'll ever want. I strongly urge you to see this movie. Christopher Plummer is his usual brilliant self, and there is a stellar supporting cast.

I love Christopher Plummer but this movie was a waste of his talents. I knew the entire story line within 10 minutes of the start. Christopher Plummer's character didn't seem to know it because he stumbled through the film like he was in a daze even though everyone else who watches the film should know immediately what's going on. If you ever saw the movie "Angel Heart" with Mickey Rourke and Robert De Niro or "Memento" with Guy Pearce and Joe Pantoliano then you know how Remember will end. Unfortunately though, unlike those movies, this film has only a few dramatic moments and the best one doesn't come until the very end of the movie.

Some people might think I'm being insensitive because this film deals with the Holocaust, but I really am not. I've seen tons of Holocaust movies that were extremely powerful and moving. But Remember isn't one of them. There is no character development at all so you have no emotional connection to Zev Guttman, the character played by Plummer, or his son, or Martin Landau who is one of Plummer's friends in the nursing home. And after about 20 mins, you get tired of watching Plummer try to figure out what is happening to him. He's losing his mind and you are being bored to tears. There is a surprise character by Dean Norris who played the DEA brother-in-law in Breaking Bad. In fact, the scenes with Plummer and Norris are some of the best ones in the movie. But they come too late in the film.

I'm sorry, I cannot recommend Remember. It's very important not to forget the subject matter, but the movie will vanish from your memory shortly after you see it.

I watched this yesterday and would love to discuss this movie with someone, but it contains too many spoilers without to do that. So...I will wonder a little about some things in Zev's early life. His journey to find men on his list from the Holocaust, while having dementia, had me feeling slightly anxious throughout and the third of the four encounters had me almost as riveted to the spot as the last. I felt like I was there beside him which attests to Christopher Plummer's wonderful acting.
I had no expectations, I knew it got good reviews but was thought of as "implausible' by many but still a very acted movie. I was captivated by it from the first 5 minutes and any implausibility didn't impact the movie for me at all. Fine performances by all.

I also liked the "extras" on the dvd version from the director/writer.

This is one of those slow-moving films with little action, yet it ends with quite a surprise after which the viewer goes "Holy Moly, I wasn't expecting that!"  To say much more would be spoiling the film.

Christopher Plummer is Zev Guttman, an old man suffering from senile dementia.  He is an Auschwitz survivor who recently lost his wife Ruth. He is in a nursing home in which he befriends Max (Martin Landau), another Auschwitz survivor who lost his entire family.  Max convinces Zev to hunt down Rudy Kurlander, the man responsible for killing off their families, but there are five Kurlanders across the country.  Which one is the one?  He visits each one and crosses them off the list.

Zev has a mission to fulfill and despite his dementia, remains calm and committed.  People are willing to help him.  His search takes him across the country and even into Canada.

When he finally meets the real Kurlander, well, pay attention.
Fabulous movie, doesn't go where you expect it to, and the performances by Martin Landau and Christopher Plummer are outstanding, well worth watching.

Interesting premise but boring, improbable and EXTREMELY slow and even more boring as it predictably wends its way leftward.

And no you cannot just stroll into a gunshop and show your driving license and walk out with a Glack 9mm, while displyng obvious signs of dementia to the shopkeeper, and no he will not thrust a gun upon you to make a quick buck.

I am familiar with EVERYthing portrayed in this piece of crap, and was a private eye for decades (know where everything is and how it all works), and I can tell you this plodding mess seems to be a bunch of made up garbage that should not interest even a Captain Planet/Mr. Rogers Millennial. It distorts reality beyond a breaking point and is clearly part of what has sunk America into utter confusion and chaos, to the point where They will now be mixing Mileys urine into the plastic of her next CDas a marketing Plus (benefit).

Good Luck with that....
